Patch Set 15: Code-Review-1

Abandoned

No further discussion from submitter, both maintainers have weighed in.  The resolution here is to fix the non-conforming firmware update implementation.

Why?
Why 6 mins instead of 5 mins? Why does bmcweb need this change ?

Because during IFWI Full Flash, writing to mtd partition is taking 5 mins or a bit more sometimes. So in order to allow enough time for the write and Task ID status/percent completion update this increase is required. otherwise task was aborting.

Please add to the commit msg :) 
IFWI is  Intel FirmWare Image ? Is that something documented in openbmc? Can you say code update instead? If you do use IFWI, please explain a bit more on it.  

Looking for a commit msg body that is at least a couple sentences.
Done
We typically require a "Tested" tag
Done
replied the comment given.
replied the comments given.

Please wrap commit msgs at 50/72. 
We follow https://cbea.ms/git-commit/ for commit msgs
Done

This is a 5 minute timer between updates to the status API.  Considering that for a progress API, I would expect updates every 10 seconds or so, 5 minutes seems like more than enough, and the bug likely lies in your implementation of firmware update.
since we are updating SPI region in IFWI full flash which is using blocking call and it is 64MB file, so its taking more than 5 minutes and so the increase in timeout value.

>  is using blocking call 

So don't use a blocking call in the dbus handling thread?  That's a well trodden pattern in openbmc to use async calls, or spin long calls into their own thread.
The TaskIdKeepAlive Timeout is made configurable now, So that it can be updated depending upon the OEM's Firmware update capabilities.

please fix your backend implementation.  updates should be sent at 10-30 second intervals.  5 minutes is a very long time to wait for updates, and should be fine as a default for anyone with conforming implemntations.

Agree Ed. Ideally this TaskID timer should be in 10-60 seconds interval. But unfortunely the current value is 5 Minutes which is too high.

From Intel also, our current implementation is not updating the TaskID status periodically especially in large file updates. So we are working internally in changing implementation to periodically update taskID with status/percentage.

Current commit makes the upload taskid keep alive timeout configurable via meson options. It makes a way for OEM's to finetune this numbers depending on the OEM specific configurations and implementation.

> Agree Ed. Ideally this TaskID timer should be in 10-60 seconds interval. But unfortunely the current value is 5 Minutes which is too high.
> 
> From Intel also, our current implementation is not updating the TaskID status periodically especially in large file updates. So we are working internally in changing implementation to periodically update taskID with status/percentage.
> 
> Current commit makes the upload taskid keep alive timeout configurable via meson options. It makes a way for OEM's to finetune this numbers depending on the OEM specific configurations and implementation.

Given that we know this is the incorrect solution, and is largely just working around a bug in another component, I don't want to take on maintenance of a per-OEM option for this, especially given that component is in an Intel fork, and not part of openbmc/openbmc where it could be simply fixed.

If there are 3 or more companies that think this is the right solution in the long run, I'm happy to discuss, but until that happens, this isn't something I think we want on master.

Thank you for the submission though.  Certainly an interesting problem.

1) This commit makes the taskID keepalive timeout as configurable value. So that OEM's can configure the value depending on processor speed. Also default value is set to 5 minutes, which doesn't change existing flow.

2) From design point of view, Leaving OEM's internal implementation, This enables to keep bmcweb design to be able to configure the keep alive timeout to lower(as default) which is ideal design as you also mentioned above.

Considering above two points ( No change in existing flow, and enhances the design to configure ideal), Can we move with code change?

> 1) This commit makes the taskID keepalive timeout as configurable value. So that OEM's can configure the value depending on processor speed. Also default value is set to 5 minutes, which doesn't change existing flow.

yep.  I think we’re on the same page as what this patchset is proposing.

> 
> 2) From design point of view, Leaving OEM's internal implementation, This enables to keep bmcweb design to be able to configure the keep alive timeout to lower(as default) which is ideal design as you also mentioned above.

no, I did not mention this as ideal.  applications implementing the interface in a reasonable way, with incremental updates is the ideal.

> 
> Considering above two points ( No change in existing flow, and enhances the design to configure ideal), Can we move with code change?

no.  as written, it is proposing an incorrect and user hostile dbus interface with no incremental updates.  the right fix is to fix the backend, and considering this is oem, that would mean this can easily stay as a patch until the oem firmware update is upstreamed, but even then, my recommendation is to please fix the backend.  I’m not interesting in maintaining complexity in configuration values that only exist because of oem backends that have odd behavior that could easily be fixed.
Done

The Oem firmware update code upstreaming may be not acceptable if its not followed the generic firmware update methodology which OpenBMC is followed, IMO. But i am not right person to comment on those Oem Firmware update methodologies.

W.r.t bmcweb: Looking at current scope of change and ideal design view, I feel this change(Making keepalive timeout as configurable) simplify the bmcweb maintenance and more adoptable. 

If you still think, This change has hard dependency with oem update backend code(which i can't visualize), Then we can keep it as patch.

> The Oem firmware update code upstreaming may be not acceptable if its not followed the generic firmware update methodology which OpenBMC is followed, IMO. But i am not right person to comment on those Oem Firmware update methodologies.
> 
> W.r.t bmcweb: Looking at current scope of change and ideal design view, I feel this change(Making keepalive timeout as configurable) simplify the bmcweb maintenance and more adoptable. 

I don’t agree with you in this regard, and unless I see more folks requesting to publish broken backends, I’m still going to recommend fixing the bug in the firmware update daemon.

> 
> If you still think, This change has hard dependency with oem update backend code(which i can't visualize), Then we can keep it as patch.

recommendation is still to fix your backend, but if you’d rather keep a patch, that’s up to you.


please don’t mark this done when the discussion has not concluded.  it had the appearance of shutting down discussion, which I’m sure you didn’t intend.

> > The Oem firmware update code upstreaming may be not acceptable if its not followed the generic firmware update methodology which OpenBMC is followed, IMO. But i am not right person to comment on those Oem Firmware update methodologies.
> > 
> > W.r.t bmcweb: Looking at current scope of change and ideal design view, I feel this change(Making keepalive timeout as configurable) simplify the bmcweb maintenance and more adoptable. 
> 
> I don’t agree with you in this regard, and unless I see more folks requesting to publish broken backends, I’m still going to recommend fixing the bug in the firmware update daemon.
> 
> > 
> > If you still think, This change has hard dependency with oem update backend code(which i can't visualize), Then we can keep it as patch.
> 
> recommendation is still to fix your backend, but if you’d rather keep a patch, that’s up to you.
Sure Ed, We will work on fixing Intel specific updated code to keep the task alive. But one thing i am not visualizing is: What is the maintenance complexity with changing variable to configurable parameter which you could visualize.
> 
> 
> please don’t mark this done when the discussion has not concluded.  it had the appearance of shutting down discussion, which I’m sure you didn’t intend.
yeah, I didn't marked the "resolved" but could have auto checked which i didn't noticed. Sure, I will keep it open.

> What is the maintenance complexity with changing variable to configurable parameter which you could visualize.

There is no ability to test if it's functionally correct, and if we're not following dbus best practices, bmcweb can no longer make certain assumptions.

Tomorrow, if the update daemon now takes 7 minutes, because the image got larger, the param will break again.  If you update the progress interface as expected by that code, there's no time limit whatsoever, and code can take as long as it likes.
I have no idea what an "IFWI full flash" is;  Can you please document the actual test you performed, which generally involves some sort of redfish command.
his feature is to support the BIOS/Host SPI chip full flash without dependency on external hardware.
Fixed the comment.
Replied the comments.
Replied the comment given.
"bmcwebExtendTimer" not giving correct meeting. You can rename it to "uploadTaskKeepAliveTimeout" or something similar.
DOne
NIT: Why is this showing as change. Just check and revert, not in scope.
Did the changes same way as the other configurable item http-body-limit. Need to remove?

Min & Max values doesn't seems to be appropriate.
Min:0 - Doesn't make sense. Timer can't expire immediately. So make it something meaningful such as 30 seconds.
Max: 60 - This is in minutes. So max can be restricted to 10 minutes.
Done
Existing default timeout value is 5 minutes. So stick to existing value.
Done

Raname the object from "extend-timer" to something meaningful. ex: upload-task-keepalive-timeout. Same in other places too.

Description also not appropriate. Please do change is accordingly..
Done

Currently its in minutes, But 5 minutes seems to be too high in normal scenario. There should be some process which should keep the task alive in periodic basis. So ideally it should be in seconds. So make it "seconds" instead of "minutes".
Done
Replied the comments.
Tested ?
Yes.
Do update the test results in commit message.
Done
replied the comments.

Is this in minutes, can you add that ?
Specifies the code update task keep alive timer in minutes.
yes, ok.
why + 1?
As updateTaskKeepAliveTimeout is a constant with default value as 5 min.
Still not clear, why +1? Default value should be the one which is getting configured and that should be applied as is. Please do correct ( Remove +1) the code.
ok, removed + 1 and made the default value as 6 now. Though the existing value was 5 so had kept it as 5 only before.
Replied code review comments.

This isn't what we had before..
Why should we change the default?
